iFixit's teardown of the 13" non-Touch Bar model reveals that the SSD isn't soldered and can be removed. Refer to step 10: https://www.ifixit.com/Teardown/MacBook+Pro+13-Inch+Function+Keys+Late+2016+Teardown/72415
Yeah, read about that yesterday after I commented. The non-touch bar model has a removable SSD while the touch bar models don't. Really weird. You'd expect it to be the other way around.

WRITING.TEXT: Slightly off topic... Apple should make a charger like a measuring tape. None of this folding would be required and at any point, the length of wire that is out of the charger would be just the length that you need. So if you're closer to the charger, then you're desk doesn't have multiple folds of wire on it. That said, it should also have the lock mechanism like a measuring tape if you do want a longer cable than the distance b/w the socket and the laptop for easy maneuverability or whatever.

I'm an iPad Mini 1 user who migrated to an iPad Air 2. Get the 9.7" one. You won't regret it. The 9.7" takes up lesser space than you might think. But the extra screen real estate makes for an amazing reading and surfing experience. In fact, whenever I have to read a PDF document/textbook I strongly prefer to read it on my iPad vs my MBP and every single time, I feel thankful for having taken the 9.7". And I've watched many a TV Show on the 9.7" whereas doing so on the Mini just felt plain uncomfortable/not so fulfilling.

I use an Air 2 and my room mate has a Pro 9.7". While the speakers are better on the Pro, I can assure you that you won't be let down by the ones on the Air 2. Both of them are excellent. My Air 2's speakers put out surprisingly loud sound. For on-bed watching, they are more than enough. Audio has never been an issue.
I wonder why it was discontinued.

Why is it that a space held together by largely gravitational interaction (spherically symmetric) is cubical?

But why would you apply cubical boundary conditions to a space which is more likely to be spherical? Is it that what goes on inside won't be affected by the boundaries? But then we are interested in the boundaries too.
Exactly! We have *evolved* to become oxygen consuming life forms right? So, there may be other types of life forms too. My question is what is it that is needed to create that first spark of life?

Major breakthroughs happen only because of the many small revelations before them. I don't think Einstein's papers would have come out if the Michelson Morley experiment hadn't been performed. And the reason for that experiment to be performed is staunch belief in existing theories and the need to **confirm** them.
I'm sure. But given our understanding of the Primordial Soup and evolution, I thought there might exist a decent definition of the difference between a grain of sand and a cell.
I was using sand as a proxy for the non living.
I can see something similar even in iOS. Especially prominent with the iBooks icon. The orange background is stationary and when I move my head sideways, the book moves along with me. I wear glasses.
The paper that they wrote was submitted on 21st November. http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v542/n7642/full/nature21360.html

I'm an iPad user: 1) Proper keyboard support. I find it half baked right now - forcing me to lift my fingers up and swipe. 2) Better split view in portrait. Screen should be split up and down, not sideways. 3) Option to set defaults - browser, pdf editor, music...
Fair point. Maybe the split keyboard can be opened by default? But many people might not like that.
